channel.title: InfoWorld: Wireless
channel.description: The latest on Wireless from InfoWorld

item.title: RIM CEO: Patent reform still needed
item.description: The U.S. government is moving in the right direction with its efforts to reform its patent process by making it tougher for companies claiming infringement to get court injunctions, said a top executive at Research In Motion (RIM) Ltd., which settled its own patent fight in March.
item.author: Grant_Gross@idg.com (Grant Gross)

item.title: China promises crackdown on mobile piracy
item.description: A promised crackdown on pirated mobile downloads will give mobile content provider Jamster a needed boost in China, the company's top executive said Wednesday.
item.author: Sumner_Lemon@idg.com (Sumner Lemon)

item.title: Companies flock to snap up .mobi names
item.description:
The newly created .mobi Internet domain for mobile device sites is shaping up to be a pretty entertaining place, if you're 10 years old.

ADVERTISEMENT

The IT Evolution
A new wave of innovation is rolling across the IT industry. Learn more at TheITEvolution.com, compliments of IDG and IBM.
item.author: Stephen_Lawson@idg.com (Stephen Lawson)

item.title: Nokia opens its mobile browser code
item.description: In a bid to encourage the mobile phone industry to standardize on a single Web browser, Nokia on Wednesday released the source code for the mobile phone Web browser it developed last year.
item.author: Nancy_Gohring@idg.com (Nancy Gohring)

item.title: AT&T, partners to offer RFID managed service
item.description: AT&T Inc. wants to make RFID (radio frequency identification) easy for enterprises, teaming up with some big-name partners on Tuesday for a managed service and technology development.
item.author: Stephen_Lawson@idg.com (Stephen Lawson)

item.title: Intel outlines plan to bridge India's digital divide
item.description:
Intel will train 800,000 teachers for free in India over the next five years as part of a global strategy to integrate technology into the educational curriculum, company President and Chief Executive Officer Paul Otellini told reporters Tuesday in Bangalore, India.

ADVERTISEMENT

The IT Evolution
A new wave of innovation is rolling across the IT industry. Learn more at TheITEvolution.com, compliments of IDG and IBM.
item.author: John_Ribeiro@idg.com (John Ribeiro)

item.title: Motorola introduces Q smart phone at last
item.description: The long-awaited Q smart phone from Motorola debuted Monday, nearly half a year late and facing tough competition from the likes of Research In Motion's BlackBerry.
item.author: Stephen_Lawson@idg.com (Stephen Lawson)

item.title: Imagining a day without Microsoft
item.description: Did you ever hear the warning, “be careful what you wish for, it might come true?” Well, because Microsoft is the company most people love to hate, I decided to ask a cross section of industry cognoscenti this simple question: What would happen if Microsoft and all of its technology disappeared tomorrow?

item.title: Nortel chief sees UMTS consolidation
item.description:
Nortel Networks Corp.'s top executive expects a consolidation of the UMTS (Universal Mobile Telecommunications System) business but won't say whether his company will be on the buying or selling end.

ADVERTISEMENT

The IT Evolution
A new wave of innovation is rolling across the IT industry. Learn more at TheITEvolution.com, compliments of IDG and IBM.
item.author: Stephen_Lawson@idg.com (Stephen Lawson)

item.title: San Francisco to push Google on privacy
item.description: San Francisco will push Google Inc. and EarthLink Inc. for greater privacy protections than the companies outlined in their proposal for a citywide wireless Internet service, officials said Friday.
item.author: Stephen_Lawson@idg.com (Stephen Lawson)
